Name: The Hidden Reality: Parallel Universes and the Deep Laws of the Cosmos

ReviewList.Text: Usually, people who have studied extensively in a particular field can only communicate their knowledge in a manner which is incomprehensible to someone who has not.  Brian Greene has a writing style which does not patronise the reader or over-simplify the very complex subject-matter, but which does enable a curious lay person to get a grasp of it.  I would definitely recommend this book to anyone who has heard about "the big bang", "parallel universes", "black holes" and "string theory" - perhaps through reading science fiction - and who would like to know what it's really all about.

In the opening pages of this sparkling gem of science writing, Greene emphasizes that he is not convinced that there are other universes and that the reader,even after completing the book, should not be convinced either. His point is that we can only have confidence in the reality of those things for which experiments and observations have provided conclusive evidence. Instead, Greene gives an impassioned argument that mathematics has time and again given us an early glimpse of things (like black holes, the expanding universe, radiation from the big bang, etc) that later observations confirmed. The Hidden Reality is about how various recent mathematical developments in physics are pointing toward the possibility that there are other universes. Greene guides the reader through these fully mathematical explorations without math but with his trademark crystal clarity. By tackling head on the important questions of how we might one day test these ideas--a theme the runs throughout the book but for which two chapters are specifically devoted--the book grounds the journey, and shows that his interest is in educating fully, not blinding with science-razzle-dazzle. And what a wonderful and remarkable journey it is.

Best book to date I've read on the subject - and I try to read them all.  It reads easy yet still contains very up to date conceptual material to give it scientific substance.  I fealt we might have strayed a little on the topic of simulations, but it was a brain teaser and has given me cause for reflection.  Brian, if you read this - Give us another book soon that keeps us on the leading edge.  Do the project jointly with Michio Kaku and it will be unstoppable.  Joe from Virginia

The subjects of multiple universes, quantum physics and other laws of the universe both intrigue and confuse me.  Trying to wrap my mind around such theories is not often helped by articles and books on the subject, not that they are written poorly, but possibly the opposite, and my high school educated brain just isn't sophisticated enough to absorb them. But this book is different, and for that reason I am very grateful.  Mr. Greene writes for people like me, he uses words, images and examples that most anyone can understand, at least for the most part. He also suggests a few times that he is going to delve a bit more deeply into a subject and allow those who are less educated on the subject a "pass".  He does not insist his views are correct, but lays out all of the possibilities that he believes could exist.  This is great stuff, and I loved it.

What is real? This has been a question of mine for a long time. From a physics perspective Brian Greene explores the question in his new book The Hidden Reality, Parallel Universes and the Deep Laws of Cosmos. While he's a physics professor at Colombia University, he writes in layman's language as far as such esoteric concepts can be expressed outside of mathematics. It took me two months to read the book – not a page turner but a thought provoker. I recommend reading the last chapter first to get an over view of the nine multi-verses Greene systematically explains in the book. Basically, the idea is that there is more than one universe, but there isn't agreement about how many and how they manifest. Of nine multi-verses that may be possible, the one that blew me away (well, all the theories blew me away) is the possibility our world could be someone else's computer simulation. Shades of the move The Matrix. In the beginning of the chapter on” Black Holes and Holograms – The Holographic Multi-verse,” Greene refers to Plato's allegory of the cave – that we are people chained facing the back wall of a cave watching shadows of the real world. That our perceptions are but a faint inkling of a far richer reality that flickers beyond reach. Greene has written two other excellent books – The Fabric of the Cosmos and The Elegant Universe (both PBS NOVA series as well). Take a stab at them.

Wow!  I think my mind has been officially blown!  I found this book, written by string theorist/physicist Brian Greene, to be an eye-opening account of the various (yes, there are SEVEN) multiverse theories.  Greene does a great job explaining these abstract speculations and the hard math that supports some of them very well. The various graphs & drawings help tremendously.  I am not at all a science-head (though I do program databases) but Greene's cogent explanations got me through some very heavy concepts, from the Quilted to the Bubble Universe; and from the cosmological constant to string theory.  I find myself exiting the book with so much more knowledge than when I began!  FYI, there is also an excellent YouTube documentary on the multiverse in which Greene himself stars & is able to illustrate his various examples.  All in all, a tour de force of information!

Should have been titled something like "The Crisis in Physics". Two stars not so much because it is a bad book per se, but more so because it champions the pathetic state the field of theoretical physics has fallen into. Instead of sheeding light on deep questions, the field has progressed to being no better than quack religion with mathematical justification. The real value of this book is that it exposes the rediculously speculative world of modern physics. The closest thing to a parallel universe is the way a blank canvas - perhaps with a random smear of paint on it -  is dubbed "profound" by the intellectualy void world of modern art. After reading this book I am convinced physics is at a dead end.

For a mere simpleton, such as myself, Brian Greene offers valuable insight while still keeping the information and thoughts accessible to laymen. It is a fine balance, to not exclude the novice nor the professional, but it is managed with very few exceptions. I can highly recommend this book to anyone who is interested in the subject, but feel that some of the literature available  is a bit intimidating.

I am a big Brian Greene fan and was very much looking forward to his latest book.  While a little familiar with the subject matter (Multiverse, String Theory, etc) he once again shows that you can take even the most complex subject in physics and break it down for non-physicists with little or no math.  It did drag on a bit but overall I would definitely recommend this book to physics junkies like myself and those just curious on the latest curiosities to come out of theoretical physics.

By Mind-blowingly Awesome, I mean the concepts conveyed in the book.  The writing is superb and easy to understand for even non-mathletes.  Still it takes a while to absorb some of the incredible ideas this book has to offer.  I was not surpised at the quality of the book, having read Greene's previous 2 books.  I was amazed at how much further science has progressed and how much further he was able to take some concepts.  If you want to be blown away about the inifinite possibilities of our universe in a relatively easy to read book, this is a great choice...highly reccomended.

This book is not written for physicists or theoretical mathematicians, but for the educated lay person.  I had to pay attention closely while I was reading or start the paragraph all over again.  But the concepts are so imaginative and exciting, I had trouble coming down from the reading experience.  For me, it was not night time reading, but a brilliant, inspiring imaginative experience.  I recommend it to all my friends who are interested in science without reservation.

As with his other presentations, Greene engages the inquisitive child deep inside us.  He takes no sides.  Allows the reader to (to use his word) "embrace" natures mysteries on our own.  I would have loved to have studied under him, from first grade onward.  Start from his first. Read his latest.

The idea of parallel universes dates at least to Murray Leinster's famous short story, "Sidewise in Time."  Long used as a device by science fiction writers, it has emerged in recent years as a serious idea in both philosophy and physics.  The late philosopher David Lewis, for example, argued that parallel universes were virtually a logical necessity.  Among physicists, particularly cosmologists, the existence of parallel universes has become a fixture of a wide variety of theories.  In this well written book, Brian Greene provides a tour of several versions of the idea of parallel universes.  These range from the consequence of conventional ideas of an infinite universe to extremely counterintutive ideas that we exist in a series of infinite computer simulations.  All of the parallel universe ideas presented by Greene have important features in common.  There is no direct evidence for any of them.  To varying extents, they are consequences of cosmological or other physical theories.  These theories enjoy varying degrees of support.  Some, like much of quantum theory, are very well supported by experiments.  Others, like the string theories used to reconcile general relativity and quantum theory, are without any real experimental support.  Inflationary cosmological theories occupy something of a middle ground with some empirical support.  Greene does not shy away from pointing out major gaps in knowledge and problems with theories.  In the course of discussing the different ideas of parallel universes, Greene discusses a good deal of modern physics and cosmology.  He is a fine writer and his expositions are good to excellent.  This book leaves the impression that some kind of multiple-parallel universe is a basic feature of reality though which version and whether there will ever be empirical support for their existence is unknownable at this time.

I bought this book along with another two books from this author and I must say I loved them! Great book if you're an average Joe interested in physics, Brian Greene explains it in a way that's both simple and fun to read.
Very, very interesting book though sometimes it was a bit over my head. However the author is adept at writing for the general public, always striving to explain sometimes very difficult concepts.

What if the universe as we know it were only one of possibly many? That is the fundamental question behind this latest book by physicist Brian Greene. Greene takes a very simplistic approach to things as he explains how scientists believe that our universe is not alone on its own & also describes the theories behind possible alternate universes & what they might look like. In each subsequent chapter we go further & further in depth into the concepts behind each of these possible variations in the multiverse & experience numbers on both sides of an extraordinary scale. It helps that while you don't have to have a complete understanding of current studies in the world of astronomy, physics or cosmology to make this book make sense. No matter what the thought that there could be other versions of us out there somewhere is still fascinating & proving this will be even more fun. Definitely a read for any of us who've wondered if parallel realities exist.
Gets a bit difficult for the layman to understand, but overall very intriguing and informative explanations of mind blowing concepts.
This book is very interesting, it's clear and I recommend it for all people interested in science, even if they aren't scientifics.
Gives you all of the possibilities that multiverses and parallel universes can exist.  It would seem there are enough for anyone.

I love these kind of books. They are simply thought provoking. And by simply reading just a few pages here and there can be a mind workout itself. I believe Brian Greene is a great inspiring author and scientist. If you don't really know him, I urge you to look him up on TED Talks (I'm sure one of his videos will grab your attention). As for the book, its great - with its inspiring conundrums life has right in front of us and more we want to figure out. I pulled out one example of the many but within the book, Greene shows us how a 52 deck of cards can be arranged in 80,658,175,170,943,878,571,660,636,856,403,766,975,289,505,440,883,227,824,000,000,000,000 different ways. And if you want to know why/how we know that, you'll just have to buy the book...and rush to page 31..

Brian Greene is a wonderful communicator of the deepest ideas behind modern physics. In this book he explores the ideas behind the main theories of possible parallel universes. Many reviewers have covered the main comments which I would have reviewed so I will not repeat them. In contrast to other reviewers I would like to offer one caveat; bear in mind that many of these ideas, while fascinating, are currently unproven. Therefore, while this is a great book always bear in mind that physics must demand that ideas are subject to experimental verification. Enjoy this book and its exploration of the forefront of modern cosmological ideas but never forget that mathematics, no matter how elegant, are not a proof of reality

Been reading this as the companion piece to Greene's "The Fabric of the Cosmos", which is helpful because it covers many of the same, hard-to-corner concepts on string theory like its ten-dimensional model of the universe to bring you back to speed, then dives into multiple-universe theory pretty quickly.  Once you picture our known universe as a bubble within a gigantic wheel of Swiss cheese; well, that's LIVING, kids.  Not finished but you guys asked me and this thing takes awhile to read and understand at the same time, but I wouldn't stop reading this for money, honestly.  You could offer me $100 to stop reading this and I'd tell ya to cram it!

I remember reading the Elegant Universe in awe of the brilliance and the conclusions that Brian Greene came to.  He has a very unique way of displaying complicated and esoteric information in a way that with a willingness to continue to learn and use google for things you don't understand, you can increase your knowledge and your information on the topics of our universe, and the cosmos for which we are all a part of.  The Hidden Reality is a superb, interesting, and wonderfully enlightening book on a topic that is slightly controversial in the Physics community.  I enjoyed this greatly and recommend it to anyone who has an eager want to learn about our universe by a master of informing us about our universe.

Brian Greene, a physist of renown, has written three books, The Elegant Universe, The Fabric of The Universe, and this latest The Hidden Reality. For any lay person, like myself, these three publications are a must, if you want to understand the Quantum, String Theory, Super String Theory, Parallel Universes, and so much more. Written at our level and understanding, this series will produce folks able to converse and think of our world, our universe and the great beyond, interstellar space. This series is the nuts and bolts of why we are where we are.

I hesitated before buying this book: to me the concept of multiple universes seemed pretty far-fetched, and some reviewers complained that the author is too philosophical and  unscientific in this book. Far from it. As a non-physicist I found certain parts difficult to follow, but by the time I'd reached the summary in the last chapter, the concept of a multiverse had become a realistic concept, and the reaons for it being a tangible possibility had become clear. This book is essential reading for anybody seriously interested in astronomy.

Actual sciece of cosmology and particle physics has evolved to the stage where it is close to impossible to describe these ideas and theories by analogees or  by models, referering to our daily experiences and our common understanding of nature.  Greene does so in a most pleasant way. It makes you feel smart (rightly or wrongly) and gives the most up to date thinking about our universe and about the ultimate background of out laws of physics in a understandable way.

If you appreciate science, like "Art Appreciation", this is amazing stuff; from the theory of string at 10-33 cm to multiverses and branes... you'll get as clear and as exciting a read as the brain can assimulate. If you liked Heinz Pagels, Cosmic Code, you will enjoy this. Also recommend Douglas Hofstadter, The Mind's Eye. Fun stuff... the mind is what the brain produces, like blood pressure is what the heart produces? Dunno...  maybe?

I'm not a physicist and never took any physics past high school back in the 70s, but this book has helped catch me up to some of the latest thinking in physics, from the multiverses and quantum mechanics, to black holes and the search for a unified "theory of everything." Clearly written with many helpful illustrations, it would be very helpful for homeschooling, science buffs, as well as folks who need to improve their "science literacy."

If you like to have your perception of reality challenged then this is the book for you. Brian Greene does an excellent job of letting you see into some of greatest mysteries in modern physics. He walks you through how multiverse theories keep popping up again and again in different places in physics. After reading this book to you will have a greater appreciation of the hidden reality that plays on behind the scene of every day life.

As if astronomy has not already expanded the known universe beyond our mortal minds, Greene walks the layman through some plausible possibilities that leave current, physical astronomy in the dust.  The scientific, philosophical and theological implications of the possibilities are enormous and humbling.  Now, if my mind was only up to retaining the sundry theories!

I think I have all Dr. Greene's books written for the general public. He can explain everything about the Universe (the one in which we exist right now, at least so we think) that they know, and that they don't know. Imagine that! Anyway, if you thrive on reading about the Universe and humanity's struggle for comprehending it,  you will value Dr. Brian's books.

As has become his trademark, Brian Greene once again does an admirable job of making complex scientific concepts accessible to the everyday reader.  Through thought provoking analogies and stories, Mr. Greene pulls back the curtain on the most far reaching frontiers of theoretical physics. A thoroughly enjoyable and educational read.
I like how each chapter is organized into 3 different levels of detail on the subject he's covering. I don't ever feel lost--even during discussions about the nature of infinity. Well, hardly ever.
If you are interested physics, string theory, parallel universes ...... Brian Greene is pretty much the leading authority. Highly recommended read.

I've read his other books and they are riveting. He does a great job of making Physics accessible to those of us who went into other fields - mine was Laboratory medicine. He's a great storyteller and the story is very, very exciting.

Warning - not for the faint-of-heart or mind!  I believe other reviews have already covered everything I could possibly say about this book - in short, it is absolutely amazing.  Brian Greene is not only a genius but skilled in conveying complex concepts in a way that is as easy to understand as the subject matter could possibly be.  I HIGHLY recommend it to everyone.  NOTE: this book WILL change the way you view the world/universe(s)!

I enjoy this book very much in spite of the fact that I cannot always wrap my mind around the theories the author is talking about; I am a 100 percent layman but very interested in the theories about the universe. I appreciate Greene's effort to explain everything in a simple way; that keeps folks like me going.

what can be said about Brian Greene (theoretical physicist and string theorist), after John Gribbin (astrophysicist and visiting fellow in astronomy at the University of Sussex) a great writer and very knowledgeable scientist.  For String theory easily the most recognizable name today.

Brian Greene does a good job with the overview of current theories for our Universe, as well as, what else may exist beyond our observable reality.  However, it was difficult to make sense of some parts without prior knowledge.  Still, a very good read!

I really enjoyed the theories of the universe(s) explained for every reasonably intelligent human, without too many complicated equations. Read it and appreciate the complexities and simplicity of the of the human mind, capable to imagine all this.

He can make the most complex Quantum Physics idea so simple and real that you can not understand why you had difficulty understanding it before this. From String theory to multiple universes, you always have that *aha* moment. Simply amazing!

The writer laid out his subject matter so that any layman could understand the concepts of cosmology.  it seems to me that these theories all need the Master architect's hand to 'begin' the events that he has laid out.  good read

This was a great read for someone not savvy in the theoretical physics realm.  It was written in layman terms which made most of the book easy to understand.  Greene definitely sold me on reading his other books!
Might be too long in my case.  The cosmos still boggles the mind and this book definitely contributes to the boggling.  Enjoyed another book by the same author "The Elegant Universe."  Outstanding.

I really enjoyed this book. I have reread it a couple of times. Brian Greene talks about the different theories of the universe and makes them understandable. I am a proponent of the Simulator Universe.
I appreciate that this book is written for someone who has less than a 150 IQ. It has been an enjoyable and educational read. I use this book as reference for some of my own projects.
He is lucid , thoughtful and always keeps things interesting making it a pleasure to understand . He builds on previous findings and confronts inconsistencies fearlessly and modestly.
Brian Greene is one of the clearest thinkers in Physics today, and all his books are well balanced to provide expert knowledge for both neophites and experts. I really enjoy them!

The Hidden Reality is an excellent armchair guide to some of the more bizarre and extraordinary ideas of theoretical physics. This book explores several candidate theories for parallel universes, while covering an extensive and chronological review of physics history and theory. What makes the content so accessible is Greene's unparalleled ability to elucidate monstrously complex ideas with clear, concise, and oftentimes humorous analogies. For the most part, Greene shows an adept command of the content, and remains both scientifically and philosophically objective; furthermore, Greene plays devil's advocate when necessary -- even to the point of making the reader wonder whether he should chalk whole thing up to Gödel's Incompleteness Theorem, as in the final chapter on mathematical reality. Having said that, the density of several ideas (e.g. Higgs fields and potential energy curves, the string landscape, probability waves) in relation to parallel universes escapes even Greene's conciseness, and the most tantalizing ideas (i.e. black holes and the holographic universe) are given decidedly less attention. Nonetheless, the book is a profound read for those with an inquisitive nature and a background understanding of string theory and quantum mechanics.

Thought provoking and sometimes downright jaw dropping. Greene presents a case for why modern developments in physics may imply the existence of various different kinds of multiverses. His scientific explanations were difficult, but in my opinion, easier than Stephen Hawkings'. He has a great gift for using familiar analogies to explain concepts impossible to visualize, such as the 9 spatial dimensions of string theory, or quantum tunneling events. It turns out certain conceptions of a multiverse are a natural progression of some well established scientific theories such as quantum mechanics. Even more surprising is that nearly all of Greene's multiverses may someday be supported or contradicted by experimental evidence. Only one proposed multiverse he discusses is forever removed from any potential observation by principle. Before reading this book I had always thought of a multiverse as an obscure and unnecessary concept evoked arbitrarily by scientists for philosophical reasons. Greene managed to really shake my views by explaining that actual scientific principles give rise to various views of a multiverse. Our world is truly an amazing place that seems to become larger and more astounding with every generation of scientific advances.
One of the very best books that I have ever read! Now I have a keener sense of my place in the universe. Or should I say "my infinite places in the multiverse."

I enjoyed this much more than the last Brian Greene book I read (The Elegant Universe). I would recommend reading through all of the footnotes as you go. Greene readily admits that much of this is speculative, but that's part of what science is - building and speculating on what we already have, looking for deeper knowledge and explanations, following where the math points to. He presents the different multiverse scenarios in approximate order of plausibility, starting with if our universe is truly infinite then there must be copies of us out there based solely on the possible combinations of particles, and ending with the thought that all mathematical possibilities are manifest. In response to those who would say that scientists, or books like this at least, are going out of their way to look for an atheist explanation of the cosmos, some may be but in general I don't think so. I think the "I don't know" point just keeps getting pushed back further.
As usual, Brian Green has produced another classic.  He explains the sceintific theories anf processes in terms the lay person can understand.
Very interesting book from start to finish.  Various insights / theories proposed had interesting implications and were thought provoking.
down to earth explanation. a must read. i have the audiobook fron randomhouse audio and it is better than anything from blackstone audio.
We attened Dr. Greene's lecture at the Paramount Theater in Austin.  He was wonderful.  The book is well written.  My husband loved it!!
We live in a strange place. Too bad we'll never get to experience any of it except through books, videos and mathematics.

If you want to know what thinking outside the box means read The Hidden Reality. The Standard Model of the universe has a dozen or so constants of nature that form the "input" into the model. There are no succesful explanations of why the constants have their observed values and if one varies these constants even a little bit then the universe would not be compatible with the things that make human life possible (e.g. stars might not form.) This is the little anthropic principle - that the universe is the way it is because otherwise we would not be here to see it. The large anthropic principle is the thought that the universe need not have turned out the way it did, implying an experiment that recurs. This is the jumping off point for the discussion of the hypothetical but well-reasoned thinking by scientists on the possibilities for other universes.

As with prior works, Dr. Greene has written a mostly excellent laymans book on current research that point to parallel universes.  If you like his previous works, you'll probably like this one as well. My only recommendation is to skip Chapter 10, Matrix redux, it is a waste of ink and paper and puts a horrific stain on the rest of an otherwise well written book.  Factually there is nothing wrong with Chapter 10, I pondered all these issues when I was between 10 and 12 years old, but I discovered girls at 13, grew up and put this nonsense back on the sci-fi shelf.  To have Dr. Greene actually give this stuff print space in one of his books is sad and pandering to the conspiracy theory types in our society.  Definitely buy it, read it, enjoy it, just skip Chapter 10.
Well written and good explanations. I loved it and so did my 12 year old grandson.Makes you relies your smallness.

All it takes to read this book is some understanding of basic physics and an interest to know more...simply know more. This book is indeed a very interesting read and educates the theories of physics in kind of entertaining way. Author has used the examples which one can relate to, unlike those textbooks. I am not a theoretical physicist by profession, and have no relation whatsoever with other streams of physics either. But still this book educated me and made my thinking clear about the universe. Now, I didn't go all the way to confirm to verify the references and the claims made, but still learned something. And that's what physics is all about...continuous learning about the things around you, the planet, space, cosmos....!!!!

This book is the latest in a series of attempts to explain the world in terms non-cosmologists/physicists can begin to imagine. As such, it can only be partially successful. It asks the reader to stretch his mind, to consider the reality of the unseen and to release preconceived notions of reality. It is not a book about religion. Don't expect Mr. Greene to write a prescription for serenity or even a hint as to the meaning of reality, for he asks the reader to share the quest for understanding reality through, quite frankly, as yet untestable hypotheses. This is a worthwhile book because it challenges preconceptions and explains very dificult  concepts as well as  may be done. Stephen Hawking fans will like the book.

Quantum Theory fascinates me, and I thought I'd read all you really could in the layman's realm of Cosmology and QT - but I hadn't. Greene does a great job of explaining some of the most popular theories behind multiple universes. Some would find such infinite ideas frightening, but I find them comforting - I mean, really, how important are your problems in a multiverse of infinite time and infinite space? If you die, Quantum Theory and Cosmology are pretty close to saying "so what - there's an infinite number of other 'yous' out there." This is not an easy book to read, and the subject matter makes it almost impossible to be easy - but Greene does his best. Definite must-reading for the well-educated non-scientist.

It must have been more than a little difficult for Dr. Brian Greene  to write the kind of  broad review of a subject as enormous, yet as ethereal as The Multiverse.  Doubly so since there can be nothing definitive that comes out of it at the end.  There can be no 'The Butler did it' resolution.  On the other hand  there's a lot that's just plain weird.  For instance, it seems like the movie The Thirteenth Floor may be closer to one possible reality than, for instance,  The Matrix.  Hopefully, the answer will be neither.  None the less, Dr. Greene has crafted for us an unexpectedly wild ride.  Which ever way it turns out, Shakespeare will have been proven right again, no matter what your pholosophy may be.

This is one of those books that will test you if you are new to this kind of material or not used to exploring so many intense ideas. However, Brian Greene has a great ability to take incredibly difficult concepts and break them down into digestible bits, and that is what really makes the book a great read. There were times that I had to slow down a bit to make sure I was on track, but he does a good job at using simple examples to explain incredibly complicated ideas, and I felt like I was learning something new with every chapter. If you are interested in learning more about space and the universe on a deeper level, you owe it to yourself to get this book and challenge yourself.

I have always had a penchant for Green's books, being a future scientist myself.  While highly speculative, this theoretical work of his does an excellent job explaining current theory while making it relevant and enjoyable by the layperson.  If you are one of the many people whose interest in the universe and reality has been renewed by current scientific endeavors, this is a fantastic book to snag.  When reading it though, just keep in mind that it is somewhat fictitious as much of the material presented is hypothetical.  Still, that is how all science starts - by asking questions, and attempting to further define things.

If you have never read Brian Greene, your are missing one of the premier writers of our day. He is a national treasure,an extraordinary physicist who brings stunning clarity to the average reader on a subject (superstring and mbrane theory)which isn't an easy feat. His writing acquaints the reader with the cutting edge theories now being pursued by physicists worldwide. Personally, I would recommend that the reader start his tome "The Elegant Universe" as it contains one of the most exquisite explanations of Einstein's general and special theories of relativity, as well a very coherent explanation of quantum physics.

This is a great book, I've purchased and read The Elegant Universe, The Fabric of the Cosmos, and this title. The author has an amazing ability to break down very complex concepts in a way that makes them understandable. This book might change your perspective on the universe and your daily interactions with it, however I found I frequently had to go back and re-read certain parts to get a good grasp on the concepts so I could move on to the next chapter. I hope Brian Greene continues to publish books like these, in many ways I see similarities here between the author and Carl Sagan.

This is a book for those who wonder about fabric of the universe thus, ourselves.  It is for those who are also afraid of physics, any kind of physics.  I choose this rating because it is written not just with eloquence but also with a string of logical thoughts that make the task of reading about the universe, a delightful journey.  Take your time reading it, take notes if you need to, go back to passages you read already and enjoy your journey.  You will love this planet we all live in and will wonder... always wonder....

Using arguments based on cosmology, physics, mathematics and philosophy, Professor Greene describes speculations and himself speculates on "alternative" or "parallel" worlds that in one sense or another may exist beyond "our own".  Overall it is a fascinating book, as long as one is aware that most (if not all) of these parallel universes are basically theoretical in nature. As expected in a book by Greene, a significant proportion of it is devoted to expounding the soundness of string theory. Good light reading.

I have read Green's previous books and found them very interesting and educational. "The Hidden Reality" is, frankly, a bit beyond my ability to totally comprehend. That certainly is not the author's problem, strictly me. This book was a bit more difficult to fully understand, although I certainly understood what Green believes, I just could not grasp all the very advanced thinking now current among quantum theorists. I am sure this book will be well accepted by those in their first year at MIT, et al., whose base mathematical education far surpasses mine. At age 82 and far, far beyond formal education years, I still find many works covering quantum physics fascinating. Greene writes very well. I think I can fairly say I understood about 70% of what I read. But that other 30% is a real problem for me.

I seen Brian Green appear on C-SPAN Book-TV discussing this book he was saying that there is a good possibility that there may be duplicate copies of us somewhere in another universe that is a exact copy of our universe. It sounded fascinating so I purchased the Kindle edition of the book. Although is attempts to make Quantum Physics and the theory of General Relativity into laymen terms it was way above my pay grade to understand any of it don't misunderstand it's a good read just a difficult one I can finish most books I read somewhere between 2 to 2 1/2 weeks this one of a modest 400 pages to me 6 weeks. But I still recomend it

Dr. Greene takes a layman like me to a level of understanding of particle, super string, quantum physics that heretofore would have been impossible.  He uses simple metaphors and analogy to get your head around some pretty complex concepts.  If you are anything like me, this book will cause you to have more questions than than answers.  The audio version is read by Dr. Greene and is a great listen as well.

This is a very interesting and well written book about the different possible multiverses based on math and modern physics which do give a window into what may have preceded the big bang.  Some are more speculative than others, but all the major theories of spacetime, quantum mechanics, strings, gravity, inflation, relativity, entropy, and dark matter make more sense if there is a multiverse.

This is truly an amazing book. I am not mathematically literate  enough to assess Greene's math, but I assume that if he is making mistakes there that professionals will catch them. So I respond to the prose. Beautifully written with remarkable clarity on astonishing topics. The book is probably the most interesting non fiction book I have ever read. Thank you, David Greene!

This a well written book designed for those of us who have a little scientific knowledge and want to learn about the cutting edge of theoretical physics and cosmology. Greene uses examples and concepts people can grasp. His arguments are compelling, but cautions that only scientific proof will determine whether any of this book's premises contains truth.
Greene does a great job of using common understandable language and examples to cover some very complex and confusing topics.

This book is about the multiverse, not a universe. Dr. Greene gives an erudite and well written explanation of the multiverse, its creation, and its infinite character. The book is extremely thought provoking. However, it is a slow read. I found it fascinating but it required intense reading. If one wants an excellent book about our multiverse, this is excellent. However, be prepared to spend a long time going through it.
This book almost made my head explode (in a good way). The author does an amazing job of explaining complex topics. I highly recommend this book to anyone interested in the theory of Multiverses.
Greene is pretty much the best at articulating up-to-date astrophysics.  I'm never disappointed.  Get it if you want to go beyond the TV shows.
This is physics written in a way that a non-genius can understand.  I would recommend Brian Greene's books to anyone interested in the field of physics.

This book is not only fun to read at the gym on your tablet, it's also fantastic to read for anyone who fears science can not be explained to lay persons intelligently, this book is a fun masterpiece of popular science writing.
Brian Greene writes physics in a way a kid could understand. I really enjoyed this book and I love the way Brian present very complex topics in a way everyone could understand.

For those who may feel intimidated by the plethora of books on physics topics that contain an abundance of formulas and equations, fear not. Brian Greene has a real talent for communicating advanced concepts in simple terms. He is the type of teacher I would have loved to have in college. This book is well worth the price at many times what I paid.
Brian Greene as always is a great read. Thankyou. The book is full of easily understood explainations of complex science

Brian Greene is a smart guy and very approachable.  It's a good read, and he explains some underlying concepts fairly well.  I probably shouldn't have been trying to read it on a plane, though.  It either put me to sleep or couldn't concentrate well enough to understand sometimes; even though I have some basic idea of some of the cosmological concepts he was explaining, it definitely was not a casual read.

Another well-written book by an intelligent physicist making difficult concepts somewhat more understandable to the average guy.  Truth-seeking, be it about physical or non-physical matters, is always interesting.  Those who enjoy science and religion will find this book interesting and challenging.
Very good as expected. A really update of the Fabric of the Cosmos which I read (and hear) eagerly. If you want to be updated, read it.

I have to say that it was the TV educational series that Brian Greene was on that prompted me to read the book. I have to say that even to someone like myself who has absolutely no science background it laid out all of the theories in a manner that was easily grasped and effortlessly absorbed.  For the neophyte I say this is a must read! To those who are already holding a degree in physics it will be entertaining.

I really enjoyed this book as it made me read a few pages, put it aside, and think about what I had just read.  This book is not for those who have not read deep physics and/or math however.  That aside, this book presents issues that I had not heard about or thought about and this is coming from someone who has read a lot of astrophysics titles.

Greene has again impressed me with his combination of knowledge of physics and writing.  This book is not as good as "The Elegant Universe," but that is a high standard to live up to.  The book discusses the concept of parallel universes and why they must exist.  There were several topics he discuss which I had never considered.  High Recommendation.
Brian Greene....makes a guy wanna think.....

Brian Greene is amazing and he has the capacity to bring all things together in a commonsense way that is intuitive.  If you're able to take the time and read this, understand that he takes some concepts out to the n'th degree to prove a point and then brings you back to reality; that is, as we are able to comprehend it.

Thought I am a psychiatrist I am interested in the underlying physical reality that we have come to discover using the brain as our starting point. The role of mathematics as a creation of the human mind or as an inherent aspect of reality is an issue I have thought of before and Dr. Green's s book further elucidates this. Dr. Green as usual writes in a clear and informative manner.

Over the years, I've been a great fan of Dr. Who (British SciFi) and Star Trek. What is amazing to me and those who have since borrowed my book, is that the science is there. It's amazing. Brian is easy to read and understand...good read!

From the standpoint of common sense, physics reveals an incomprehensible world. I am a dunce when it comes to physics and mathematics, but I can fully appreciate Greene's genius at coming up with analogies to common sense that render the incomprehensible as comprehensible as it can be.

I am no astrophysicist or anything close to it and I was very satisfied that I understood a Lot of the info in this book.  I highly recommend for anyone who has an interest in cosmology, quantum theory, string or M theory or anything in this area.  It was a good read and inspirational.
Unlike his book The Elegant Universe (which I loved) this book goes off the deep end and, for me, was pretty much a waste of time.  Would not recommend this read.

Study of the cosmos is required for contemporary citizens. It is not offputting or overly complex but rather written so that we all can understand and be made current with the exciting studies of our universe. Green is one of the top writers on the cosmos.

Brian Greene's elegant prose not only denotes his mastering of the subject but also transmits a certain sense of enjoyment that is contagious.  If you enjoyed the Nova style of presentations, this book will definitely hit your interest gene!

This was a pretty difficult book to read, but it was amazing!  I've never read anything by Brian Greene before but have always been interested in this sort of subject.  There is so much more to what we see all around us.  It's mind boggling.

Greene is the master of providing complex theories with accessability to the common reader.This book is magical in its ability to lay at one's feet the fruits of genious. Never will I ponder reality as I have before reading this book.

I ordered this new book for my wife, who had borrowed a copy from our local library and was spending a lot of time writing notes from the book.  She can now highlight her own copy.  It arrived in excellent condition.  Thank you.
Great book, Brian is a master and explaining the complexity of our universe, and reality. un-doubtfully  one of my Top 10.

I suspect this may be a 5 rather than a 4 but it's too early to tell. Typically I read three pages, close my eyes and think about it for a while, then try to regather my coherency. This could take some time.

Brian Greene is a good physicist and able to cover a complex subject well enough for a bright lay person to understand at least the essence of what can be only fully (or mostly) understood by mathematics.

Good book for lay man as well as maths and technically inclined reader. Wanted to read more discussion on dark matter and supersymmetry though. Which are hot topics and will be tested in LHC this year.

What can I say--I love Brian Greene.  Having been a fan of the writings of Stephen Hawking, Charles Darwin, Albert Einstein, etc. this book is fascinating and a wonderful addition to the home library.
This is obviously a book that many people are familiar with, but I still wanted to give it a review because it is such a great book.  Brian Greene is one of the best at explaining difficult material.
If your into reality, black holes and parallel worlds, this is the most comprehensive read.  Everything in put into laymen terms, which is unique.
This guy is perhaps my favorite popular physics author.  I've read most of his books, and this most recent one just captivates my imagination, especially eternal inflation!!
Does a great job of trying to make it understandable to the common folk. I still could capture about 50% if I was lucky but it is a real mind stretcher and worth the read.
This book can be understood by the lay reader, but some familiarity with the basic concepts is helpful. In many ways, this is a mind-blowing book. I loved it.

I was intrigued by a review in the WSJ, and although it wasn't on Kindle I purchased the hard cover.  This book covers tremendously complex theories and their development and supposition by new theories.  It does this in three ways, maybe four.  It uses a lot of analogies that make complex ideas easier to understand, goes into more depth once the concepts are understood and can branch off into higher complexity which I as a non-science guy can get but perhaps not fully understand - but get enough to move on to the next discussion.  At the same time it offers more detailed and informed discussion for the more advanced.  This is very well written by someone who I think sees his personal mission is to  bring science to the masses.  Highly recommend to anyone and especially to the young who might express some interest.  A read like this could forge our next great scientists.

Brian Greene is not only an outstanding theoretic physicist, but he is also an amazing science communicator. In his book “The Hidden Reality" Brian outlines several theoretical models purposing the existence of a vast plurality of universes of which ours is only one. Brian discusses how the science of contemporary theoretical physics arrived at these ideas and details each of the concepts in a way that we can understand. He then offers ideas as to how the science may push forward, in investigating which of these ideas may be most realistic, using experimentation, observation and theoretical work. Brian’s communication skills are amazing in that he is able to describe some very far out ideas using down to earth and easy to understand language. This is a must read for anybody interested in learning where the frontiers of cosmology are in this present age.
It is nice when someone puts together a detailed viewpoints that you already are intuitively thinking about. Looking forward to any other installments...
Excellent read. A little nebulous in some areas, but I definitely recommend it to all interested in this area of science.
I get more than I expected. It's very good for me. I recommend the products in 100% for all that can get it.

This is an amazing book, written in a way that only few people can write. Greene takes you to places that are difficult to envisage with such an extraordinary clarity. The book is the result of somenone who has not only worked as a scientist on the frontier of his subject matter, but someone who also has the ability to tell a story like the best of them. Despite the possible room for controversy regarding the topics that are presented in the book, this is a fascinating account of the best that the human mind can come up with.
Everyone who likes to know what's happening in the world of cosmology loves this book, me included.
Green does a very good job of using laymens terms to try to explain some very difficult concepts.
An open-minded discussion with in-depth knowledge about the universes in most modern context.
His usual excellent presentation for the layperson. A bit long on some of the details.
Excellent all the way around. I would buy from them again. Very satisfied overall.

This is one of those things where I'm not sure whether the issue is with the book, or the issue is with me.  ("It's not you, it's me.")  I love science, but this was a little too hard for me to read. On the other hand, if Brian Greene dumbed it down a little I could see someone else saying "why is it so basic?"  I guess I'm just going to stick with the Nova shows on TV.
Surprised me how many different ways there are to think of a multiverse.
Exactly what I needed.  Quick delivery!  Very pleased.
A great romp through the possibilities of existence…

Brian Greene and other String theorists are trying to do a nearly impossible task, a task never successfully performed before in human history. They are trying to discover the origins of the universe using mathematics (since experimenting on the origin is a few billion years too late!). From the book I get the impression that they're not quite there yet. One of the things which constantly bothers me about books like this is that scientists use all these terms that are not themselves understood. There are 11 dimensions. (Fine. What IS a dimension?) Time slows down at high speed and in intense gravitational fields . (Great! What IS time? What is a particle? (A string, maybe?  Ok. What IS a string?) What is a field? (A disturbance in space? Ok. What IS space?)

Awesome book. I know little about quantum mechanics and physics but this book teaches you so much. I read a few pages and my mind travels to the possibilities of other worlds, other universes. It's so amazing. Best book I've ever read - really.
I am reading it slowly- but it is fascinating.

It's baffling when readers give this book fewer stars because the subject matter is challenging. This is not "The Da Vinci Code". It's particle physics, string theory, and an exploration of the cosmos (or multi- mega-verse) narrated by a physicist whose passion for the subject is infectious. However, if your idea of relaxing is settling in with the Sunday NYT crossword puzzle or better yet the Harper's cryptic puzzle, chances are you'll love this book and subject matter in general. If you're looking for a beach read, you might want to try The Universe In A Teacup.
Brian Greene does a fine job at "dumbing it down" for the general public.  He has the ability to make difficult concepts within the grasp of a lay person interested in physics.
Great book. Brian Greene ROCKS!!!!!
"Professor Greene writes stories that make  quantum physics and the multiverse universe make sense even for those of us that never got beyond long division."
Grab a board and surf on spacetime for this one.  Greene spells it out, but it is up to you to use your imagination to see the limits of the possible.
This is a very great book. I highly recommend it. It covers a great many things and explains them as clearly as possible.
great product and service

I found this very hard going and it took me a while to try to understand the concepts even to the extent I am capable. But Professor Greene makes understanding this complex subject as easy as possible through metaphors and well thought out consistent explanations that avoid jargon and that do not require mathematical training. This book opened my mind to concepts and ideas that I had never thought about before. If you want light reading, skip it. But if you want a scholarly explanation of Quantum theory and the multiverse, I have never seen a better explanation. I bought  copies for three of my closest friends so we could have discussions and expand our understanding. All of them have also found the book deep and enlightening and we have had several in depth discussions about these concepts as we all work thru these new ideas. I recommend it very highly if you are ready to do the work.

When I was a teen I used to go outside at night and stretch out on the hood of the family Chevy and just watch the night sky.  My family thought I was strange.  I was just curious.  I've always wondered what was 'out there'.  About a year ago I watched The Elegant Universe on PBS.  That was my introduction to Brian Greene.  I liked how he explained the universe and string theory.  By that time, also, I was hooked on Fringe, a science-fiction show on Fox, whose plot involved parallel worlds.  Then this book was offered by Amazon Vine and I ordered it.  That's the evolution of how I came to read this book.  However, did I understand it?  Absolutely not!  I didn't expect to.  I did read every word of it though.  It'll probably take me a lifetime to understand half of it, but like I said: I read it for the possibilities.  Now, back to writing my romance novels.  Those, I understand.  :o)

I have worked my way(s) through the Quilted Multiverse where space is infinite [there is no clear division between each parallel universe] and the Inflationary Multiverse where there is a clear division between each parallel universe as they are evolving. From contrast, I move to comparison: parallel universes emerging from inflation generate quilted parallel universes and parallel parallel universes over time [being fluid]. Table 11.1 summarizes various versions of parallel universes, including quantum [many worlds], holographic, simulated, and universal [principle of fecundity]. Greene concludes, "it is only through the rational pursuit of theories, even those that whisk us into strange and unfamiliar domains, that we stand a chance of revealing the expanse of reality." Hmm. . .

goes far beyond most books of the type. Brian Greene is one of the best writers for non-fiction that i have encountered... enjoyed tremendously. Not often you find a physics book that can grab you like this.
Very exciting book
What I expected

I love this set of 12 CDs because it allows me to replay them until I understand what is being said about the Universe, Multiverses and Parallel Universes.  Wonderful information stated clearly and with enough explanation for a layman to "get it", at least to some degree.  I recommend this to those who are curious about things we were never taught in school. Such exciting new information, bringing together many different areas of quantum physics and other sciences.
Great book.

Brian Greene is very interesting as always.  However, I did not feel that this book came up to the high standard that he set with with his previous two books: "The Elegant Universe" and "The Fabric of the Cosmos".  A condensed version of "The Hidden Reality" probably would be much better.  It seemed to me to be much too wordy and there were times when I felt like I was wasting my time reading it.
Item delivered on time, and was as described.

I found it to be a little too deep for the average layman to understand.  I never did quite understand what a multiverse is.  Is it little universes inside our universe or is it other universes outside our universe.  I like Brian Greeens's writing but this I ended up scanning towards the end rather than reading because I was somewhat lost. Inciently I have a Chemical Engineering degree.
Difficult subject for the lay person. A good attempt to simplify by the author but either additional simplification was needed or subject just beyond laymans grasp.

I bought this for my husband and he loves it.  He constantly reads about and watches programs (including ones with the author) about science and cosmology.  He would recommend this book to others of the same ilk.
great
Great
Green is a genious who has the gift to transmit complex knowledge to non cientific people like me. I enjoyed all his books. Both fascinating and enlighting.

Modern physics is pretty much devoid of the capacity for proofs of the theories of the very small and the very large.  Consequently, theories abound which have very little possibility in my humble opinion of either being correct.. or of being proven correct.  Mathematics is driving the more believable theories, whereas philosophy has become a force in some.  Greene is a good writer and very adept at providing analogies of very complex theories that at least allow us to ponder these deep subjects.

Brian Greene talks about the math of the universe. If the universe is infinite the the possibilities are infinite also. Brian Greene suggests some of those possibilities and they are startling. Most of his ideas are not original with him but have been thought about for more than a hundred years by various scientist. Although they may seem like science fiction we may be on the verge of proving them correct. This is a very interesting read.

Brian Greene's latest book on the mysteries of modern physics looks at several models that hypothesize the existence of parallel realities or "multiverses" as the author refers to them as.  The book is written in a manner that seeks to present these ideas to readers who may not be versed in math and physics, so many analogies, graphs, and diagrams are used to illustrate what is being presented. Greene acknowledges the limitations of science and the reality that our understanding is always evolving.  The book is well organized and it clearly explains at the outset the author's approach to presenting this subject.  Nine different models of parallel universe cosmologies are described and Greene examines how we might or might not be able to test these theories. This book shares pieces of the history of theoretical physics along the way, weaving tales of persons such as Bohr, Einstein, Schrodinger, & Heisinger into the discussion of what has led up to the theories outlined in this book.  I found this material to be understandable and Greene's approach to be pretty balanced and sensible.  This book is thought-provoking as it invites us to consider the philosophical implications of what physicists are uncovering about the nature of reality. Greene is adept at explaining these subjects in a way that the general public can follow along, so for those interested in these subjects this book would be a good overview.
Great boot! Received on time. Very satisfied with the services and I recommend to a friend!

I haven't actually read this book yet, but have skimmed through it briefly.  I know I'll be reading it, when the time and opportunity is right.  Brian Green has an interesting writing style that brings the message to a 'none scientific' type person, across well.

Great book if you love science. Also great if, like me, you're not too well versed in physics jargon because Brian Greene breaks it all down into layman's terms. Came in great condition as well. I definitely recommend it for any closet science nerds!

This is not an easy book to read, even for readers of books in this genre. And the reason is likely that it is filled with so much airy speculation that it's hard to get a grasp of anything substantive. The positive part of the book is that Brian Greene devotes substantial effort to explaining the extremely abtuse and befuddling theories that some people believe suggest our universe is just one of a countless number of other ones. Why the recent attention on the multiverse? Stephen Hawking and Leonard Mlodinow in The Grand Design are honest about the present dilemma in scientific theory: Natural laws, the constants of natures, the geometry of the universe, and other cosmological factors seem nicely tuned to allow humans to exist.  But this fact suggests a designer, which cannot be tolerated in our current scientific worldview. Thus, in place of a designer (or at least a need to explain the apparent design other than by luck), a growing number of scientists are now joining the multiverse bandwagon: with an infinity of other universes it's easy to explain this one; ours just so happened to have the right configuration of particles and forces to allow life to exist.  But is this an explanation or a cop-out? As Paul J. Steinhardt, one of the leading contributers to the inflationary big bang, recently wrote in Scientific American, "a theory that predicts everything predicts nothing." The unavoidable hole in The Hidden Reality is that Greene never puts science's quest for the multiverse concept in perspective and leads the reader to think that science is merrily on its way to discovering a host of unknown worlds; all it needs is larger particle accelerators, quantum computers and more time. But science does not need the multiverse; what it needs is another approach to explaining the one real world we know about.
Can't wait for Brain's next book.
Difficult, not easy for anyone who has a short attention span. Complex ideas, although well-written and concise. A good read, nonetheless.
Purchased this book for a retired educator, who loves to teach her elementry school kids about the universe and the stars.

Fine writing and excellent explanation of elusive concepts, but ultimately it just bored me about mid-way through. Probably better for readers with more science background than I have. I thought it would have made a nice magazine article, with hyperlinks to more details. But, to each his own.

Brian Greene is able to cut through the clutter and make a very complicated subject accessible. Reading this book will not let you understand string theory, branes, multiverses, etc. on a deep level, but you will end up with a very good understanding of what all the effort is about. The book goes to great length to explain that the picture generated by string and M-theory may not be the road to reality, but it does give a feeling for the strangeness of our universe and some of the underlying features that must be present in any final theory. It will only be as some experimental results become available that science will be able to distinguish between some of the many flavors of string theory and hidden reality that appear to underly our simple 3-D appearing universe. I would recommend reading the first half of Greene's "Elegant Un,iverse" before tackling this book if you have any previous training in quantum mechanics and relativity. Greene gives an excellent review of these subjects in a way that makes you wish he had taught you the subjects in the first place. More than once, I thought, "Oh, that's what this was about". If the current ideas about the underlying mathematics of the universe prove to be wrong or incomplete, then you will still have a good introduction to the road leading the "theory of everything".

I bought this for a friend of mine who has a very scientific mind and enjoys this type of book. Prior to giving this book as a gift, I read through a few chapters and found it to be what some would call "not an easy read". It is science after all. I did find it interesting eventhough it could be somewhat challenging for the non scientificly inclined. I have to admit that I have not read any previous books by Brian Greene and that could be of matter here.

The Hidden Reality is a great book. It lays out the strange realities being considered by scientists today. And it avoids the "gee-whiz", "isn't this cool?" approach of many pop-science books. In fact, calling this pop-science is  misleading. This book takes the reader through the myriad steps that explain WHY scientists are considering the possibility that there might be other universes. Which means the reader has to do some brain stretches to grasp how physics got from the old days of Newton to the new vision. The work pays off in spades. Without an equation in sight (well, some are in the endnotes), you climb the mountain of physics and take in a grand vista. Even if physics isn't your thing, you will find yourself swept by Greene's narrative.
It seems like the underlying theme is "trust me, this is physics, not religion". It's interesting and fun to read but the preaching gets in the way.
ok

Great book, but it suffers from a very poor Kindle implementation: Footnotes and *s are hard to access using keyboard arrow keys; page titles often appear at the bottom of the previous page; figures are sometimes split between pages causing confusion; links to some figures are not correct; going back in text to a previous page and then paging foward often causes text to re-flow causing confusion; multiple *s are lumped together at the chapter ends with no distinction between them. Also, price was too high - out of line with similar items. Hardcopy book was cheaper at my local bookstore.

Hypocrite book, whose essential aim is to conceal from the lay reader the substantial failure of string theory. Greene's narrative unfolds as if, in today's physics world, we were witnessing a growing convergence on multiverse thinking. This is simply not true. Only string theorists *need* recurring to the idea of a landscape of many different universes. But string theorists should better apply the Copernican principle to themselves, too: they should accept that, in physics, we live in a multitheory environment, in which string theory cannot play a uniquely central role any longer.

Greene writes like he hates you.  He's boring despite talking about some of the most fascinating things of our existence.  I don't think I would ever buy another book by this author, even should he discover the meaning of life itself, I'd pass and wait for another author to sum it up.
VERY DIFFICULT TO READ. I HAVE  A GRADUATE DEGREE AND WAS A PHYSICS MAJOR. I FOUND THIS BOOK DISAPPOINTING AS I THOUGHT IT WOULD BE MORE CLEAR IN ITS CONTENT AND WRITING. I DO NOT RECOMMEND IT...!
